Bitcoin Diamond (BCD) Rise and Shine like a Bright Diamond in 2020

Bitcoin Diamond (BCD) cryptocurrency payments facilitate great convenience and efficiency for merchants and customers. The transactions are verified in just a matter of seconds. Merchants are glad because they are protected from high chargebacks.

Bitcoin Diamond (BCD) was designed to work as peer-to-peer cash in a way to match the functionality of traditional fiat currency. The major intention of this Bitcoin fork was to solve the problem of slow confirmations and to deal with the issue of having to have high threshold requirements of Bitcoin.

The BCD pay is useful because merchants can offer their products and services without having to go through the burden of expensive processing fees. Since there are no chargebacks, it is suitable for merchants, and they are less affected when dealing with indecisive customers.

Ayobami Abiola, Crypto Enthousiast and Writer at the Currency Analytics, tweeted: “The upcoming Bitcoin Diamond halving will help the cryptocurrency extend well into the future. We need to see how the reality unfolds for the BCD after halving. Will it rise and shine like a bright diamond?“

The Bitcoin Diamond facilitated BCD Bazaar is the first crypto-only store. The products are hand-picked. The BCD pay facilitates an international market place, where it is possible to have access to the products regardless of where the buyer is from. The BCD pay International exclusively accepts crypto, and it is possible to make purchases with Bitcoin and BCD.

The products in this Bazaar are from the best and popular online retailers who are curated to serve the global market place. Products are hand-picked and added in the Bazaar more frequently.

Those who love electronic gadgets and toys would not want to miss what is offered at the Bazaar. To get started, users need to get a digital wallet, Buy BCD, and pay with BCD. The minimum order limit is set at 212.45 BCD.

Bitcoin Diamond (BCD) Convenient than Credit Card
Bitcoin Diamond (BCD) is hailed to be more versatile than Cash and more secure than fiat and far convenient than a credit card.

Bitcoin Diamond (BCD) is better than fiat being a fork of the Bitcoin Blockchain. The supply of Bitcoin Diamond is limited, and therefore the inflation is kept under control. I hear lots of people saying "who needs a headphone jack in 2020"...
Well, lots of people still use the jack. Don't assume no one does just because you don't.
Wired headphones/buds are generally better quality for cheaper.
It gives the option for people to use their existing headphones or gaming headsets.
Travel somewhere and forgot your Bluetooth headphones? Just Grab a cheap set as the grocery store and you're good to go/make do until you get home.
If you're using Bluetooth headphones and they go flat, just plug in any headphones you got laying around with no downtime.
PRICE: Really cheap wired headphones/buds do the job quite well for people on a budget. (really cheap Bluetooth buds/phones are rubbish).
Bluetooth headphones are an extra thing to charge, and and extra charger to keep track of.
Wireless buds aren't cheap and can be easy to lose, including accidental drops into irrecoverable areas, left in pockets and go through the washing machine etc, (wired are at least attached to your phone)
If you're plugging your phone into a PA system, wired is a much better option for both audio quality and reliability. (plus there's not many decent PA bluetooth receivers).. it's so frustrating to have to carry around and keep track of extra dongles for those times when someone hands you their phone and wants to play a backing track etc from it.
Ok you might say just put up with using a dongle.. but what if i need to charge while using the dongle?.. ok you can get aftermarket dongles that can do that, but that's extra $$$.
For something so simple and cheap to include, it's frustrating for those who want it.. I own a flagship device without a headphone jack and I hate that I don't have it, When I ordered t I didn't realize it didn't have one. But, the mid tier phone of the same brand has one included! Why would the premium phone have less to offer?
The only reason I see for companies not including one is that they want people to purchase Bluetooth headphones to make an extra sale.

It's going to be an awesome phone with great software because that's what OnePlus do. Having said that, their absolute BEST "budget" offering was the X that Nord is constantly being compared to; but it's not really anything like the X because the X was a repackaging of previous generation hardware for $250. SD 801, three gigs of RAM, AMOLED display (first for OnePlus) in a glass/aluminum assembly. Flagship specifications from just the year prior to its release with arguably better build and display compared to the OnePlus 1 and 2. FOR TWO-HUNDRED-AND-FIFTY DOLLARS. Going through the hassle of using new components with entirely new designs is never going to net that same value. OnePlus is still incredible, but has long-since lost focus on their original mission. Nord exemplifies this tremendously.

As far as how much "design" you can make when it comes to putting 3 circle, the L shape is completely different from the triangle of the iphone.
I mean, the other design options are:
1. vertical bar
2. horizontal bar
3. L shape
4. triangle
3 and 4 are noticeably different in that the third camera is either aligned on either of the other two, or is between the two.
There's absolutely nothing unique or "design" worthy about any of this, your point on it being "design infringement" is complete BS.
It's like talking about the "design" of the screen: It's a fcking rectangle. That's it. Maybe you put a dent or a hole in it now, but it's still a rectangle with more or less rounded corner.
Really, even the "design" of smartphone is mostly very minor stuff. They're all more or less slabs with glass on the front, glass/metal/plastic on the back, and whatever on the edge. Corners are more or less rounded, edges can be rounded, and sometimes you have ugly stuff like rounded backs and curved screen.
Even the colors are mostly the same shades of gray + "gold" + "pink", although there are some notable exception.
There's way too much talk about """design""" when they all look pretty much identical.

This really showcases the risk smartphones companies make towards a design aspect. I think of Apple and how they need to create a design to months or a year in advance before the design is revealed to the public.

How do you know you have a correct vision of what a future phone needs to look like that far in advance? Or do you go for something tried and true and just slightly different.

We wish a grand change every time, but really, they need to risk on a design far in advance for production, and going with something that works seems like a safe business practice in the long run.

Definitely took the design process for granted before this interview. MKBHD, keep on doing the great work!

One thing that was not explained in detail was research and development. R&D is a big component in pricing.

Take the iPhone X for example. Each iPhone X cost a bit over $400 to manufacturer, but to be able to fold the display ribbon behind the display itself costs a lot more because the yield was low. Face ID had issues as well during production. A lot of these components were "sacrificed" in the process so Apple could get the best parts, then they sold those to consumers at a price that would still bring Apple revenue.

I work on a semiconductor facility, the process as a lot people knows, can get pretty complex too fast. Growing up and looking at the greatest devices and their price tag always gave me the wrong impression of how much something is worth <whatever that might mean to you as a individual>,then going to school changed my mind one more time, and then walking into a fab and looking at the process changed it all around one more time. R&D, machinery, experienced workers , and marketing, office, etc gets to be crazy, there is truly somethings you can't assign a value too but that at the end of the day you WILL HAVE TO PAY FOR. I might be more of a snob in certain things tech related so I don't think so much of the price tag <even if I'm not rich by any means> but rather the implications of a certain implementation and price to performance ratio. it really takes a lot creative individuals to drive a manufacturing, design of a product into that direction.

Now that I know the difference in costs between an AMOLED and LCD displays, I personally consider LCD a much better option, because of not only the price but also its longevity (LCDs aren't affected by burn-in issues). When it comes to IP rating and NFC especially, I think that these features are well worth it at least for me.
I also wonder about how much it costs to provide software updates. How big of a difference in a phone's price would it make to extend support for it for two more years or so? It's a shame that a thousand-dollar Android flagship usually receives one or two major updates and that's all - it would be well worth it to pay a little extra at the beginning to receive updates for a longer time.

) Once a well-known organ transplant expert in China, Shen Zhongyang was recently purged by the Chinese communist regime and removed from the National Committee of China’s Political Consultative Conference.

Shen was a former director of the Center for Organ Transplantation in Tianjin Central First Hospital and the Liver Transplant Institute of Armed Police General Hospital. On the Tianjin Central First Hospital’s official website, Shen was introduced as “a renowned organ transplant expert.”

According to the hospital’s website, “In 1998, he established the first organ transplant institute and trained many organ transplant workers. He led the team to assist nearly 70 medical units in the country to perform liver transplantation. In 20 years, he and his team completed more than 10,000 liver transplants.”

On the website of China’s United Front Work Department, it says that under Shen’s leadership, the Central First Hospital performed 5,000 liver transplants by 2010.

Another introduction about Shen on a Baidu Baike (Baidu Encyclopedia) page, it states that Shen completed almost 10,000 liver transplants by 2014, making up a quarter of the country’s total liver transplant cases.

Shen’s involvement in such a high-volume of organ transplants reveals a dark, state-sanctioned crime in China––the killing of Falun Gong practitioners and other prisoners of conscience for their organs.

The History of Organ Harvesting
Unlike many countries with established organ donation systems, China doesn’t have one. Due to the influence of traditional culture, Chinese people prefer to keep their bodies intact after death and not many of them embrace the idea of organ donations introduced by Western medicine.

It was known that the Chinese communist regime was using organs from death row prisoners for the transplants needed by high-ranking officials. But due to the limited number of prisoners and the health conditions of their organs, this was only done on a small scale.

After the Chinese communist regime ordered the persecution of Falun Gong, a mind and body practice, since July 1999, the number of organ transplants skyrocketed. In April 2006, the ex-wife of a surgeon who was involved in removing organs from living Falun Gong practitioners came forward to expose the crimes to the world.

I think most people think in terms of BOM, even at a cafe like "why I am paying 8$ for coffee" etc, it's really hard for most unless part of the process to consider the downstream costs following the materials, especially unfortunate as the material usually isn't the biggest cost in the chain.

I don't think that's really true. I think most people that actually consider the BOM also realize that the true cost is higher than just the BOM. The problem is that even when all the additional costs are factored in phones are still way over priced. Most phones are like 50% profit. That's especially true for flagship phones.
@MrSkullhead0 labour and rent cost. Central London location is not cheap.
@MrSkullhead0 Not always, it depends on the cost method, the process used to manufacture the good, and the overhead present.

A few thoughts:
Removing the headphone jack is better for the manufacturer, but worse for the consumer. You can't use just any old headphones, you have to go out and buy wireless headphones, which are probably worse in terms of sound quality, and you have to charge them which is probably annoying. I don't use wireless headphones myself since everything I own has a headphone jack but I imagine it's not quite as convenient.
When it comes to phone thickness, I would be happy if my phone was 50% thicker. When I take the case off to clean it, feels so incredibly thin and fragile that I would never want to use it without a case and it's actually hard to hold. If the phone was thicker, it would be easier to hold and have more room inside for things like the battery and hey, maybe even a headphone jack.
And personally about displays, I don't really care. I don't know why you need high refresh on a phone, I don't know why you need it to be so pixel dense on such a small screen. It sucks the battery and most likely doesn't improve the experience as much as they think.
I would have liked to know how much camera modules cost, since it's now common for phones to come with 5 cameras.

Lmao. Really dodging those headphone jack questions. It's okay, we all know it's an excuse to sell your expensive proprietary bluetooth ear buds.

Dude, Bluetooth is literally an open standard. There is no such thing as “proprietary Bluetooth ear buds”. You can use any Bluetooth device from any manufacturer of your choosing and it will work with the phone.

And he literally gave you the answer to why they don’t include it. The growing adoption of wireless audio devices means the compromises they need to make to include a jack are no longer worth it.

Not really dodging them, he said it as it is; Bluetooth headphones are becoming more popular and more affordable, and therefore the demand for headphone jack is decreasing.

It makes sense to reduce the total number of ports on a device that you want to make water proof as well as eliminate parts that people aren't asking for.

There is one point that I am not sure that you made clear in your closing comments, MKBHD. The "bill of materials" for most products sold either online or via retail needs to be less than 50% of the retail sale price. So, when we talk about $4 or $15 on a supposedly $400 phone, we are really talking about a total bill of materials that is $200 or less. A regular consumer will look at the retail price of 400, 500, etc and ask "Why can't they afford that extra $4 (or what appears to be 1%)?" Please consider explaining in addition to the bill of materials, the necessary profit margins because that $400 needs to cover the cost of manufacturing, the marketing, the people who designed, built, and assembled that phone, software implementation and coding, and other operating costs of a large scale business.

It has been quite some time since oled has come down in price, with 5" oleds costing just as much as an LCD at one point, why did it ramp up again?

Because they are usually curved which significantly ads to the cost (lower yeild, more complex tooling), that and they now have better more expensive polarizers that increase color and light emittance (HDR & higher nits). Lastly they have higher refresh rates & lower response times.

Another add to cost is the inclusion of pinholes for cameras.

Even though the NFC only costs 4$, or an AMOLED is twice the price of an LCD, there are thousands of other factors to consider. As Carl said, and tried to explain, there's development and integration with other parts to have in mind. So when you ask if 4$ is something we'd like to pay for NFC, it is never just the 4$.
It's 4$ for the components, yes, but hundreds of man hours for development, coding, PCB design, mechanical design to allow for the NFC to read tags...
A BOM is not something a consumer can remotely calculate the price of a device from

Some thoughts regarding HIFI car audio and the absence of a headphone jack on Android phones:
Many cars have the options of bluetooth, USB or 3.5mm jack for streaming music through the car audio system. Bluetooth is ranged as the worst regarding audio quality but is the most "user firendly" option. USB is usually considered the best option, but with lack of support in later Android versions, most cars require an iPhone for that. So, for the Android users caring about high quality audio, the best option is a phone with a headphone jack and a decent D/A converter. I personally have a OnePlus 6 which has is equipped with such, but I don't know what to actually go for next time I buy a new phone. I really care about the sound in my car, but if I have to be left with bluetooth as the only streaming option, I might actually switch to iPhone...

What most of people forget when they criticize one product (no matter if it's a smartphone or a car, or any other product) they forget that behind it is a business. They do it to earn money, it's a huge industry and each option we cry after that comes with extra $ spend to product that good. NFC 4$ it's said, well multiply it by let's say 1mil smartphones. That's a bit of pure math, add at it the IP rating, add the headphone jack (that's a huge price because limits the space for other components, so adding it will makes the design of hardware even more expensive)... We should stop cry for something a smartphone lacks and try more understand the build process and be happy for the overall user experience by using it... An interesting idea: Why can't we assemble the phones - like we assembled PCs in the 1990s. How about a company who can build customised phones for the consumer.

All d components inside the smartphone is built and optimized to work with each other. Your new shiny camera won't work as well with your old processors and screens. Like pc, it is only as good/fast as its slowest components. However, unlike pcs, smartphone components costs more when bought separately instead of the finished product from the factory, because factory buys bulk, and those components are not individually wrapped.

Hence why google abandoned project Ara
@Rishabh Kadkol My bad, true.
@E Ado Yeah I had heard. However, no major company took this up.

You need to consider the difference in the market and the factors involved. PC assembly was and still is a thing because desktops are still sold everywhere for very different purposes. If you are a casual user who just needs a PC for internet browsing or entertainment at home you can buy an all-in-one or a pre-built PC. If you are looking for a gaming PC, you can buy pre-built or go custom/self assembly. If you are a working professional that needs powerful machines for work you can buy pre-built (Macs) or again, custom/self assembly. The PC market is inherently customisable and diverse because of the sheer diversity of its target market. For phones, there's not much diversity in the target market. Most people just want to buy something that works out of the box and that's it. There's no need for proper "gaming phone" because the games available on phones are made to be run on all high-end phones anyway. There's no need for "DSLR quality camera" on phones because people who need that kind of camera quality would just go for an actual DSLR or mirrorless etc.
Not only that, as others have mentioned there is another factor where establishing the parts manufacturing itself will be an issue. The PC market already has a well established parts market because of the diversity of the target market as I have mentioned previously. Customisable phones require multiple manufacturers to invest into making the parts instead of just one (look at LG G5 and how it failed with the whole modules idea). Customisable phones are unprofitable and is too risky to start. That is why even with the might and money of Google, Project Ara never came to fruition.
RIP project Aura!

Am still wondering if his answer to the headphone jack question 11:52 is enough to justify its removal.
@Mr. J I think this is the best answer.
@shirokiちゃんねる, never had an issue playing a game using my AirPods. If your device crumbles down under load it's definitely not the wireless technology to blame.

@David B, why would a business spend money on product development when you can stick a standardized port and call it a day? Market needs a motive to evolve, because otherwise there's no point.
Apple went out of their way and got rid of it in the iPhone, applying the necessary pressure on the competition to drive their products forward.

@Kuronosu Kami You make a fair point, and I really haven't tried anything besides the big players in the game. So no doubt there's some audio tech companies that are doing great things in the wireless space.

I suppose I'm not the average consumer in this respect either because I hook up to a lot of gear that does utilize the 3.5mm jack. Older vehicles with aux inputs, hooking up to a PA system, connecting to my electric drums and using the somewhat expensive headphones I already own. Being nickle and dimed for USB-C to 3.5mm dongles when I own a $1700(CAD) Note 10+ because they can't include a component that costs 5 cents in this massive beast of a phone. The struggles are real, and it pisses me off on a day-to-day basis.

@Matthew Croft you make some good points. And with the issue with recycling that's more on the Apple specific side of things. They've made the Airpods so impossible to service that recyclers just straight up won't deal with them(numerous sources available on this).

In regards to your point on the volume of space inside the phone, to your point about them being aircraft carriers, exactly that. No one is going to put anything beyond 5000mah in the phone anyways, so it's not like that extra volume will even be utilized. Maybe if they used the extra space to have removable batteries it would be easier to swallow.

I've worked as a mobile phone technician and in the cellular field for over a decade. I'm all for changes to adopt better tech with more of a focus on consumer friendliness. I just don't understand the merit of gutting a low cost feature and trying to switch to platforms which have not reached product maturity. Where having both the 3.5mm, USB-C and wireless could all be consumer options.

It's just this whole Apple got away with it so we can too! Next thing for sure will be the charging brick. Afterwards everyone will jump on board and be singing the virtues of environmental impact of charging bricks. Really it's just something else to chisel a little more out of consumers. Apple's lightning to 3.5mm jack became their number one accessory (even though they included one in the box when it hit no 1.)

Maybe I just really fucking hate dongles. : )

The issue with oneplus 8 was because of qualcomm has pretty much the monopoly of mobile chip market. Unlike the 855, 865 came with mandatory 5G chip in it, making every single flagship phone this year must be 5G. The "problem" with OnePlus is that hardly anyone in the general public knows the brand. Here in Europe, only the tech savvy know it, but if you ask someone on the street they`ll only know Samsung, LG, maybe Sony and Huawei of course. Thats not too bad if you want a unique phone but it gets bad when you want to sell your OnePlus. Since only the tech people know the brand and what it can do youll hardly get a penny back - with a samsung or iphone you get the most in resell-value. Something to keep in mind and the reason whats keeping me from buying another OnePlus, since I change and resell my phones frequently to keep costs low. Also - all people think you have a Samsung and when you tell them no its a OnePlus they think you have a cheap "china-phone", although their flagships actually cost more than samsungs...

I think there is a way to have both, it’s not an either/or situation. The reason unboxing videos are more prevalent is not because people think they’re better, but because they’re easier to make, especially for the rising Youtuber who’s still learning the craft of the trade and trying to make a name for him/herself in this very saturated field of tech video making. Sadly the YouTube algorithm prefers quantity over quality, it’s something many Youtubers have complained about. The reason behind this is that YouTube cares more about the amount of money they can make from ads than they do about your enjoyment from watching every individual video, and unboxing videos are much easier to make thus you can make more videos over the same period of time, thus more ads for YouTube to make money from, and as a reward you’re more likely to have your video to land on the recommended section on viewers’ homepage. I’d blame this on google’s greed rather than the tech channels themselves.

This was super interesting, and so refreshing to see a phone manufacturer so open. It's great to see OnePlus return to it's roots, what made it so great in the first place, offering a great phone at a reasonable price. Not everyone wants to or can afford to buy a $1k+ phone, not everyone wants to spend $50+ a month on a contract, I certainly don't.
I've been a big fan of OnePlus ever since Google shafted it's budget/mid range users by killing off their Nexus phone, I had a Nexus 5, and I loved it because it was pure Android, light weight and fast, no bloatware or clunky UI that many manufacturers add. I then bought a OnePlus 5, for 2 reasons, price, and the lightweight OxygenOS that compliments stock Android rather than adding to it. I'm now rocking a 6T, but you know what the Nord or it's successor might actually be my new phone.
I bought my 6T, and pay £10 for my sim only contract, so I'm in no rush to change the 6T unless it gets damaged, it does everything I need it to. I don't need a 120Hz display, I don't need a gaming phone, I don't really watch content on it that often, that's why I own a TV, as long as all my daily driver apps run smoothly and phone and/or video calling works great then I'll be happy.
Manufacturers could learn a lot from this, your average user is similar to me, and they wanna spend $200 to $500 or contract equivalent maximum. Manufacturers will claim "but we can't make a profit if a phone is X amount", but if the phone is a reasonable cost then they'll sell more units, thus driving down the unit cost.

Yea, I wasn't confused - i was thinking of Carl. Pete I knew definitely has a stronger accent. But even so, I felt like Carl was different in this interview.
I'm not sure if it's just the script for each launch or what but there always tends to be a bit of awkwardness especially for OnePlus during their launches.
I know I've seen that similar feel with other product launches from other mainstream companies but I feel like it's more pronounced for OnePlus.
However, having Marq just sit down and chat with Pete - you could tell Pete was more relaxed and enjoyed describing what goes through his mind
during the product creation process and pretty much sharing some of his vision.
Because I'm not going to lie, I often view >>SOME<< of the smartphone product industry as picking a price and figuring out how many random (or how little) features you can cram into that budget line and hope it sells.
Now I know he said they didn't want to go over $500 - but he brought it back to the strategy and what He believes the consumer would want based on their feedback and then going from there. And that says a lot.
He didn't just think - oh the consumer wants a cheaper product so let's throw some specs into a chassis and sell it. But rather he looked at the main points the consumer brought along with that desire for a lower-priced product and formed a strategy based on that. Definitely a cool interview.
One thing that's interesting is that for those wireless charging fans, the only place they can go for a budget phone is pretty much the SE2.
Unless you wanted to buy an older gen flagship like the s10 or even s10e. But those are still more expensive than the SE2. ( Unless you're outside of the US)
Cause from what it sounds like, you're not going to find it in the Pixel or Nord budget segment. I don't even think Samsung offers It on their A-series.

What they're doing with the Nord is the same as what Apple did with the XR. Overprice your flagship to make the midranger's price (and downgrades) more palatable. Except now there's stiff competition in the midrange with the Pixel 4a, iPhone SE, and various Chinese brands. This is exactly what I suspected could happen when Oneplus started significantly increasing their prices over the past few years. If you're buying in the flagship range, the price gap is smaller than ever between a Oneplus 8 Pro and a Samsung/iPhone and people could just decide to make the jump. And now that there's many exciting options in the midrange price, where Oneplus used to be king, it's going to be tough. For me personally, if the Nord is anywhere near the same price as the 4a, I'd pick the 4a. If I'm not getting an 800 series processor anyway, which is the one advantage Oneplus held over most phones in the midrange in past years, might as well get the awesome Pixel camera.

Removing the headphone jack might not give you more battery, but if you remove it you also remove an entry point for water, thus making it more “waterproof” (more like water resistant). The market is moving in the direction where electronics have to have some kind of resistance to liquids, so it only make sense to remove weak points, and personally after breaking many earphones by getting them yanked out of my ears, wireless headphone/earphones are truly amazing. Eventually the sound will be just as good as wired, even now it’s pretty good.

This whole marketing idea that all products from a particular company have to look alike is dangerous and stupid. Carmakers have been making this mistake for over two decades now. There are several insurmountable problems with it. First, when the "design philosophy" is fugly, you are hurting the sales potential of your whole product line, not just one model. Second, you are severely limiting yourself as to what you can do and preventing yourself from making positive changes. Third, that's the whole point of company logos: the vehicle can be wholly different but easily identified as a specific brand if you just put your logo on it. Duh. Last, but definitely not least, styling that looks good on an SUV looks terrible on a coupé and vice versa. Companies that are trying to make all their vehicles look alike, whether they want to admit it or not, are finding that to not be a successful strategy.

I think nickel-and-diming a phone is too short-sighted to everything going on with the manufacturing of a phone, and the long-term support we expect from these devices, as well as any accessory that might be coming out later for it as well.  If we have a product that is reliable and solid, and well-made, and everything, and the company stands behind and maintains on a regular basis, then it will go a long way towards the overall price of the device.  As they say, you get what you pay for.  So if you go super cheap, you're going to have junk.  In your mind, take the estimated cost of the device, and divide it out across the number of months you plan on owning the device, to better equate if you can afford to adjust your expenses to include this device.  If not, then just wait a little bit and ride out the old junker that you still have.  Just like cars, sometimes the investment is so large, that the only way you're going to get all the value out of your investment is not only of course to take care of it, but to use it for as long as possible.

I’ve worked in Manufacturing & Production majority of my career, and i’ve always had that way of thinking when it comes to pricing in tech / phones. so i’m not surprised at prices these days, whereas majority of the public sees the cost/parts of the phone compared to the final pricing.

when there’s so much more into building a product such as he mentioned, design, engineering, testing, staff etc etc. but good interview. and hope more people see how the pricing comes in at now.

nankink The widely used term is "value added". Consumers don't want to pay so much for the necessary non-value added steps,  but without them you wouldn't have a phone at all. Despite being of the same importance, we focus heavily on those value added steps

Arvind Bhatiya I think people think that apple markup their prices a lot more than they actually do. In some quarters, Samsung actually had higher margins than apple even considering  the massive margins Apple gets from its services (not devices). It’s also important to understand that Apple spends a ton on R&D.

A bill of materials is not a good way to determine the overall value of a device. A large majority of the value add comes from other activities e.g. hardware design and engineering (including R&D), software design and development, logistics, marketing communications, support, etc. For example, the value of the Sony sensor in the Pixel is not much on its own. Google’s imaging pipeline, algorithms and AI are what make it great. That being said, I understand why you asked the questions you did.

Very interesting. I bought the OnePlus One with some trepidation, having barely heard about the company. I believe I was one of the first in the UK to get one, and I really loved it. Then for a couple of years I went back to the iPhone 5 (I know, but I had compelling reasons), and always looked back longingly at the OnePlus One. So, when I had a successful Applectomy I was able pick up the OnePlus 6, and it has been a real delight. However, as a retired gent with a modest income I doubt I will ever spend more than £500 for a phone (too many other life expenses), so when the day comes I would definitely be more interested in a cheap OnePlus than almost any other manufacturer.

My thoughts?
I want:
-LCD high refresh rate screen (as high as current technology will allow at a relatively low price).
-Big battery with a focus of charge speed over capacity but still somewhere in the middle (My current phone has 5000mAh, I'd go to 4200 at the lowest for the fastest rate of charge).
-Not too thin body
-Camera focus should be on the features (not gimmicks).

Other things like NFC and even IPS ratings can be ignored. Like he said, at least One Plus does make sure their phones have some padding, they just don't spend time and resources passing tests, so I'd be perfectly happy with a phone not rated and just be careful with my device regardless like I'm we sure we all are anyway. As for NFC, not a lot of people use it, or what use it does have has aftermarket solutions you can buy if the phone you buy for all its other features lacks the chip.

@cat funt like he said, the speed of the wired and wireless charging is based mostly on the charger itself and not just the battery or circuitry in the phone. OnePlus' battery is running at a different amperage and voltage then your average phone. Just using a 40w, 60w, or 100w charger won't get you those speeds unless the charger outputs the amperage/voltage combo OnePlus' custom battery is built to. Vise versa, if you've ever tried to use a OnePlus' fast charger to charge something none OnePlus' it will do it at 1A/5V. Nothing more, even if the device can take a higher combo, because the higher combos the OnePlus charger supports aren't the standard ones other companies use.

So, no. I don't think OnePlus has plans to not ship the charger because their advertised feature specifically requires their branded charger.

On the audio jack, again because I like my wired, expensive headphones: I guarantee that with the JerryRigEverything episode there will be an empty part on the bottom or top that could have facilitated an audio jack, so does it really matter that much in space? Everything near the charging port or speakers is dead space anyways. The iPod Touch was like 5mm thick on the edge, yet had an audio jack, so I don't see the thinness as much of a reason either.
I think they just decided there would be no more jack and that's it. Not trouble like "if only we didn't need the audio jack" while designing their phones with an audio jack. The good o'l create a problem and offer the solution kind of deal.
Do the "saved costs" outweigh the lost sales? I doubt it.

Carl had some great responses but I could tell he was intentionally dodging the headphone jack question. If you look closely, you can see that he's wearing what look to be new wireless earbuds from OnePlus. It seems like he avoided talking about the headphone jack in an attempt to not make it seem like the lack of a headphone jack was done to sell more of those earbuds.

He could've just named a price, but the fact that he didn't shows that he has no valid explanation as to why there's no headphone jack in the Nord. Hell, he even admitted that he isn't exactly sure how much space a headphone jack takes up or how much it would change the internal layout, meaning he has no reason to believe that removing the headphone jack benefits the phone in any meaningful way. The argument that the headphone jack takes up too much space is nothing more than just maketing BS that actually means "we want more money, so please just buy our wireless earbuds".

It confirms what i've been thinking for a while. I'm going to keep it simple : it's always about selling more phones, making more versions, adding slightly new (or old) stuff to an already existing smartphone.
So when i think about what it costs to put nfc in a display, leaving a headphone jack...etc I end up thinking that smartphone companies care about money more than anything else.
The whole industry is like that. It's not their fault, it's the game, they somehow "got to play along" (or not).
When i see the tech that is out there, the prices of everything, i end up thinking : where are the perfect phones ?
The phones with everything. Low or medium cost, battery, durability, nfc, headphone jack, curved design without notch on the screen, powerful and hidden behind glass cameras...etc....etc (Long list)
This should exist. It's 2020. It's a bit late.. C"mon smartphones companies, wake up !

Pathetic...

@shubham agrawal Ever heard of the word "ethics" in business? People actually value it and it gains you more customers -> money.

People want 1. a phone thats durable, so not glass (making any design ireelevant, since u will use a case). Who even decided that glass is the best material for something you will 100% drop at a point in your life? Oh right Apple did with iphone 4. So they can gain money from people repairing their constantly broken phones instead of buying a 2$ plastic replacement part from ebay.
2. Removable battery, so you can replace easily and carry a spare or 2 (apple started trend also) again having to replace batteries through the manufacturer is way more profitable for them.
3. Headphone jack. Wireless audio will NEVER be as good as wired, period. The same bud will always sound better if the audio won't get compressed and transferred wireless and not to mention the logistics of losing them, accidentally washing them and having to charge them.
4. Water proofing. It can be done without glued glass body, see galaxy S5 from 2014.
5. SD card. Cant even believe this is getting rare also (apple trend) to push bigger and more expensive internal storage options.

So basically a Galaxy S5, with modern specs SHOULD be the flagship of today. Instead, we have compromises on everything in the name of profit. I am sure if a manufacturer decided to make a 2020 speced s5, it would be cheaper to manufacture (plastic body) and would have more profit through big sales.

Well, personally I’ll always go back to how smartphones are being sold nowadays. The trade offs are fine as long as the price reflects it or there are additions that compensate for those trade offs. For example the situation with the headphone jack is fine, bye bye, as long as we get at least the tiniest improvement in battery life. I don’t want to be greedy, so I won’t ask for a pair of super cheap wireless earbuds to be included, but at least something to make it feel like the trade off was worth it. And going back to the price, we talk about the budget, mid-range, and premium phones so if it’s a budget phone, to make it cheap sure let’s get rid of some things, for mid range let’s add something extra in exchange for those trade offs, and in the premium let’s make it stand out, give everyone a good reason to upgrade or make the people who get it feel like “damn, I spent $1000 for a nice device that has nice things that none of the other versions have, I’m happy about this” and not feel like “oh, so it’s just an extra camera...”. And yeah that’s what I think, thoughts anyone?

Despite being hailed as the best educational system, you have highest number of graduates crippling under student loans.

I could go on, but you get the point. It's good to feel proud of one's past, but it's also important to move ahead and shape one's future.

Device manufacturing is a really interesting topic. I've worked with an OEM before to design a device (which, unfortunately, due to financial problems never came to be), and there are a few other factors that I think are interesting to touch on.

Battery and Headphone Jack:

Although battery charging technology itself varies quite a bit in cost, the battery itself is fairly inexpensive. IIRC, it was around $0.10 to $0.15 per 100 mAh. So a 5000 mAh phone would have a battery that would cost a little over $5. The bigger issue as it relates to headphone jacks (Since Mr. Pei dodged your question) is that batteries are rectangular. How much battery actually would fit in to a space where the headphone jack goes? Maybe 100 mAh. However, the excuse that companies prefer to fall back on in the battery argument is that you would lose all of the depth of the headphone jack due to the battery being a rectangle. So therefore, that's more like 500 mAh. HOWEVER, this also makes the assumption that you are placing the headphone jack opposite of the edge of the device where there are already ports, such as the top, when the USB-C port is at the bottom. Since the two ports are essentially the same depth, the reality is that regardless of how many mAh you could fit in to the size of the headphone jack, it's a null point because the battery already does not extend there next to the USB-C port. For that matter, the DAC, which actually takes up space in terms of circuitry, is still present on the chipset for when you plug in USB-C headphones. In other words, with proper design, the cost of the headphone jack is essentially negligible both in terms of money and battery size. However, this also brings me to my next point -- USB-C.

USB-C:

Franky, USB-C has one of the most awful license models I think I'm aware of for something that wants to be a universal standard. The license cost is not only per-device (like NFC) but actually per FEATURE. Sure, you get basic charging and data with your basic USB-C port, but standard USB-C audio, display output, high speed charging, and reverse charging, be prepared to pay about an additional $0.50 per feature per device. It's easily enough to double the cost of a USB-C port, and more than enough prevent a company from wanting to put two of them on a device. Since Micro USB costs nothing at all, it's why you still see it on a lot of low-cost devices. End-to-end, using Micro USB instead of USB-C can easily shave $10 off of the final consumer price of a product. That doesn't sound like much when you're looking at a $100 phone, but if you're trying to squeeze in to the magic $199, $149, or sub-$100 price points, that can make a big difference.

Cameras:

To be blunt, camera sensors are cheaper than you think. $5 will get you a 12-16 megapixel sensor. The 48 megapixel Sony sensor you see on a lot of budget phones these days is probably around $10 (although it wasn't available when I was building my device, based on the prices I was given then, this should be a reasonable estimate). These are perfectly decent sensors with perfectly decent lenses. It's not the camera itself that costs a lot. It's the software. The drivers come from the camera manufacturer, and have to be made per the version of Android and the chipset. If you're lucky, you get a nice package. For example, the popular Sony sensors often have good drivers that use the Camera 2 API, support 64-bit Android, and have been been integrated in to the chipset's image processing capabilities and packaged up with a simple standard camera app that you can just put on the device and call it a day... if you're using MediaTek. I'll discuss chipsets more in a moment, but for the moment I'll be very direct: if you are using a Qualcomm chipset, you're less likely to have 64-bit camera drivers available, they're less likely to support the Camera 2 API, and you will need to develop your camera app in-house or purchase it from someone else. Simply put, if you have the development team available, with all the time and expertise, you can make a great camera experience regardless of your chipset. However, it helps to explain why it takes several years for especially new companies, such as OnePlus, to actually have good cameras on their devices. It's not the hardware, it's the software. Case in point, I have a $150 phone with the 48 megapixel Sony sensor. The pictures out of the stock camera app are fine, but not great. However, I can take a picture with Open Camera as a DNG/RAW, and process it, and get great results. Hidden beneath a somewhat disappointing camera UI is a great camera with a ton of advanced features. even Open Camera only touches the surface, and doesn't expose some of the options such as color grading available thanks to Sony's great drivers and MediaTek's image co-processor. But to make a really great camera experience, expect to employ a team of well-paid developers full-time. Not every company is up for that, especially not right away.

Chipset and Firmware:

The de facto standard for mobile chipsets today is Qualcomm. AllWinner chips are cheap, but slow and hot. Rockchip seems quite content with making passable chips that were modern about 7 years ago. Neither of those companies have good LTE modems. Huawei and Samsung have tried their hand at making their own ARM processors to varying success, but neither have marketed their chips outside of their own products. Realistically, the only two viable options for most companies are Qualcomm and MediaTek. Right here is where a lot of people jump in to complain that MediaTek makes slow chip that never get updates, often overlooking the comparison to similarly priced phones with Qualcomm chips. The chipset is easily the biggest single cost component of a mobile phone or tablet. For a solid midrange device, expect that cost to start around $120-$170. However, on top of that is the Android firmware itself. Both Qualcomm and MediaTek provide reference builds of stock Android, and they generally provide ready-to-go software updates, and pre-tested builds that will pass Google's CTS quickly and easily. CTS is about $5,000 to $10,000, cheaper for updates, and only needs to be done once per hardware. Costs are incurred in two ways; customizing software, and actually pushing the update to devices. Customizing software, especially on a budget, often yields a poor user experience. See LG's phones with MediaTek's chips. Phones that have the same chipset and run a basically non-modified stock firmware from MediaTek run great, but LGs are buggy and stutter. They're also not likely to see a lot of software updates on their already razor-thin margins. Realistically, the only reason cheaper Qualcomm devices tend to run better is because they often benefit from the same QA that the software gets for higher-end models. When it comes down to it, though, the time and investment in pushing out updates and fixing bugs is low priority on devices that already have very low margins. No matter if Qualcomm and MediaTek both publish quick Android firmware updates, if often simply doesn't pay to invest in pushing it to users, especially if you have a custom software skin you have to apply on top of it. OnePlus has a big benefit here in that their Android skin is light and well-polished. If you plan to push multiple firmware updates, quite simply, you have to price the device higher in order to have funds available to support it.

Memory:

Now to the last point; memory. Frankly, both RAM and onboard storage are cheap. $15 will get you 64 GB of onboard storage and 3GB of RAM. So how come you end up charged $100 more for $5 of memory upgrades? Very simply, it's related to the point above. Increased storage and memory are the easiest way to "pad" the cost of a phone or tablet. It's the easiest way to get more money to support the device updates for a longer amount of time. Or if you want your device to look like a bargain, one of the easiest ways to do so. But at the end of the day, memory and storage are cheap and are often used to compensate for the cost of the case (not cheap) or software development and updates (also not cheap).

Well, to anyone who took the time to read that novel, I hope you found it interesting.

On the question "Does this effect how you think about smart-phones and those compromises at all?"
It does and it doesn't. The thing that I keep my mind on is this: This is OnePlus, a subsidiary of BBK Electronics Corporation (the Oppo, Realme etc. brands). At the end of it, the variables change when you look into other manufacturers, their are other parts to source (some are in-house so that would effect BOM costs) etc, etc. So those compromises tend to always be through the glass of which manufacturer it is, which is different for OnePlus, Samsung, Apple, Motorola, etc.
Saying that, I do appreciate that Carl was so candid about it, as much as he can be. As their is that, which given that I am considering the Nord as I shop around, likely helps.

I've never used an AMOLED display in my life. Be it on any device. I've only been using LCD screens. From the goodness I hear about AMOLEDs, I might soon venture into a phone with an AMOLED screen but I have to overcome my fear of burning in as I stay with my phone for four or five years.

Used an AMOLED for three years (until I broke the screen) with no burn in whatsoever. I think the technology has improved far beyond that being a problem. More concerning is the lack of security updates for any phone older than about 3 years, leaving you vulnerable to scams and bank hacking. So, perhaps the length of time we can keep a phone for is reducing.
As a side note, when I broke my amoled screen it was replaced by an ordinary LCD display again. I was heartbroken at the difference. The pictures I took that used to look so vivid, bright, and detailed looked now dull. Also the battery life suffers. I'd never buy a phone that isn't AMOLED - it's worth every cent! Definitely go for it.

yeah burn in on phones hasn't really been a thing for years. it is not impossible to still do it but it is a LOT harder lol. but al long as you use auto brightness so your screen only uses full power in direct sunlight and switch to dark mode you should be fine. if you are still worried there are apps that slightly lower your pixel density so they can shift around which pixels are getting used to prevent burn in but as others have said you don't really need it on modern phones.
Ive bought s10 plus, bro trust me the amoled of Samsungs are the best thing you can lay eyes on, it looks absolutely gorgeous

I have used Super Amoled display since 2011with Nokia N9 (late October of 2011) then Samsung's Galaxy S6 ( late November of 2015 until this April ). I haven't found a single problem in the displays I've used. Believe me when I say that Super Amoled is the best display. Black especially is true black. N9's display made me never even think to abandon Super Amoled. Every time I want to buy a phone the display must be Super Amoled and after S6 the PPI's must be in a minimum of 500. I wanted more PPI's but my my current phone (OnePlus 7 Pro) has bigger screen and resolution so the PPI's can't easily be more than 550. Note that the display of course isn't the only parameter I evaluate to buy a new phone.

I have a 5y old s6 with a 2k Amoled display, and only this year I noticed a slight burn in, which is only visible when the screen is all white. I think the technology got better with time and some manufacturers have ways to prevent burn in, like shifting pixels. The key is to watch the brightness of the panel, you should keep it at a reasonable level, your eyes will also thank you.

After three phones without 3.5mm plugs, I'm done. I hate the dongles, I hate fiddling with wireless phones, I hate having to charge yet another device, I hate the artifacts in RF-intense environments and the shifts in audio quality as the headsets negotiate a new bitrate. The only in-ear headphones that stay in my ears are the Shure IEM's with the silicon plugs (triple flanged) but now I have to use a flimsy dongle to be able to use them. All of this makes me opt-out of listening to music, something I love to do. Heck, I even went and found my old Sansa Clip MP3 player.
Next phone WILL have 3.5mm, even if that really limits my options. Thicker phones isn't a problem IMO.

It'd be curious to see a comparison in power usage of driving a pair of headphones compared to a wireless chipset, though. New tech has probably made the wireless option quite efficient.
I just want Oneplus to step into the budget oriented world where they'll compete with phones which have already has been the flagship killers while keeping an edge in that budget range.

Although the companies say that all decisions towards the development of a smartphone are a „trade off“ i think otherwise. Like ip certificate, if it is so expensive and lacking of an general authority, why are they not developing their own tools to test the smartphones efficiently?! It is certainly an investment that would pay off and would take down the price of the process. I think the truth here is that cheaper smartphones do not get such features so that they have a „short“ lifecycle so consumers are forced to buy for sure a new one after 2 to 3 years and therefor they simply never get such a certificate. And the same accounts for all the other features and decisions. Do not get me wrong, i would do it the same way 100% but i think the development of a smartphone is not that scientific or difficult anymore. The industry is so crowded that every decision is dictated by margin. Sure in the beginning the consumer is important, like, which price range and whats the potential of the volumne but thats it basically it the rest is defined by costs and resulting margin.

When it comes to leaving Apple my fear is loosing the fully functioning accessibility features for the visually impaired. I don’t want to sink money into a phone that I am only partially sure I can use. If a person buys a phone through their cell phone carrier, most of the time they will hassle you about wanting to return a phone after the 30 days. Sometimes it takes a person a while to decide if the level accessibility is something they can deal with for 2+ years.

If accessibility is the main concern then definitely stay with Apple. Apple's VoiceOver is the more unified compared to Android alternatives. I'm developing mobile apps, primarily iOS, and it is very easy to create accessible interface, especially starting with iOS 13. My colleague is having problems with the Android, because various screen readers read text in different way. There's Samsung Screen reader, Android Screen reader and so on.
Stay with apple. It's great in that regard

An item may cost a certain amount on their BOM but there are other indirect costs involved like the phone real estate that it takes up could be used to house other things, the battery power it may consume, the software changes it might require. A small change can end up affecting the overall size of the phone that could not only force you to reconsider the screen size but also affect the tooling costs. So the BOM does not reflect the actual increase in price.

@Shieldmate Cost less than a dollar, but makes hundreds of profit from their wireless ones.
Almost all the advantages you're listing are on the manufacturer's side, not the consumer. Why should I care that it's easier for them to design the board? I just want the best phone for me. The S10+ for exemple didn't have any trouble being water resistant and with a large battery.

And I don't know if you're being ignorent or lying regarding the quality of cheap wireless earphones, but that's really, and I mean REALLY wrong, most 10ish dollars wired earphones sounds better than 30ish wireless ones.

Also, should I mention that it's not like we either have to choose between wired and wireless? Having the headphone jack doesn't prevent anyone from using wireless ones. Again, I don't care if the manufacturing process is easier without it, in the end all I want is a device that let me the choice to use what I want. What you guys are supporting right now is a regression in the market and the removal of choice for the consumer, I hope y'all aware of that.

@Enzo Mercier A headphone jack would cost them less than a dollar. There are other benefits to not include it, like that you don't have to design the board to be under stress and push the rubber waterproof seal against the frame. And the space you save from not having the jack, route for the flex cable and the connector with its wiring is really nice. It takes more space on the board than people think. It is a weak point that people break and another hole in the phone. Hey, Supply Chain engineer here ....
To quite clear that adding up the costs of BOM entries will lead to a very modest price for any phone really ... But the real question (to me) is how much margin phone makers gain ... Apples and Samsungs and LGs approximately share the same components inside ... But all these companies sell at different prices ....
The other point I have is about the OS : Apple makes iOS in house and that incurs a huge investment in Dev Teams .. this is not the same for Android .... Used in millions of phones spanning all ranges ... Yet prices orbit around the same reference ....

Now, about the tone of this conversation: I used to be a OP fan. I know that it sounds silly to be fan of phone brand, but I was really excited when I got my op3 and I loved upgrading to every model after it, until i reached my current OP 7 pro. This one was, by far, the most expensive phone I ever bought. I was already unsure about the direction the brand was going, but I gave it a try. It's an amazing phone, but after it Oneplus continued to make more expensive models and I had reached my limit.
Oneplus was a brand that supposedly heard the costumer base and gave them great phones, with the specs and functions that the users wanted, also, for a great price. Now they have ignored their fans over and over, increased the prices to almost reach samsung and apple levels and now they are coming out with Nord... basically a cheap version of their flagships. When people were complaining about the OP8 price they were not asking for a different phone with a better price, but for the same phone with better price. They keep ignoring their fanbase, many of whom have already moved on to xiaomi and other brands.

When it comes to product design I always have expectations on security, hygiene, measurement and fashion.

1) Security - Front and rear cameras should be covered with a lid kind of material piece where user must manually decide when to show the views around his device.

2) Hygiene - Device should sustain the chemicals which used to clean and disinfect.

3) Measurement - Extra space occupy bigger flat battery helps the processor to run at its best performance in place.

4) Fashion - Coating a muticolor paint and design behind the device which would become new trend over vintage solid finish.

IP certification, or rather water proofing in general is a super important feature to have, in my opinion, especially if you are dropping more than 500 euros for a phone. Thinking about how I always have my phone with me, at home, at the office, when I go out, vacation,etc. there is always the risk of water damage, having that piece of mind that if someone accidentally spills some water on it, or you dropped it in water at a pool, whatever... Give me a decent screen, bright, 60 or 90 hz is enough for me, waterproofing, a good camera system one normal and the other wide, 128 gb of storage with expansion possibility and a battery that can last a full day and I'm super happy. And then the SoC and ram, whatever is enough to make the phone snappy and allow me to view docs o the go, do some gaming and we are set.

I am always down, for any Tech video that goes into the Business, beyond Product showcase... I going to waveform to listen to this completely...
But looking at the specifics shared, BOM costs are more controlled and rest of the costs involved are more volatile and depends on strategy... Given the marketing Oneplus is pushing for Nord, I am expecting the costs outside BOM costs to be higher.. could be very different for another product line... But IP68 is like any other industry... you test and qualify to the Standard... if the Standard is stringent, costs are going to be higher... 15$ per phone is quite high... compared to the hardware costs... As an Engineer, I feel designing to the Standard is important, but as a Consumer, I feel Designing to survive water is important than qualifying to a standard... NFC - lets add that to every phone... I am not convinced, by the fact that headphone jack can give more space to the battery... I can get behind the fact, it makes on less thing to worry in a design, but not added battery... But Carl clearly hinted, the fact that pushing wireless buds are more of the reason than anything else to get rid of the jack...
The best question marques asked was about the headphone jack 🔥

Dear manufacturers, is it a compact smartphone with a full screen below 6inch 60hz AMOLED, 6gb ram with an acceptable soc like sd730G/sd765, 5-6 hours screen on time, a REALLY REALLY good one main camera (I don't care about the ultrawide and super zoom) and a headphone jack cost you $399 ?

Actually, I find this very interesting. It's easy as a tech reviewer to just bash a phone for NOT having an AMOLED panel to take advantage of the slight battery life increase that dark mode could give a phone. But then, we don't really take time to actually look into that LCD panel as critically as we would an AMOLED panel to check for things like:
Display Calibration (Colour Accuracy)
Off-Axis colour shift e.t.c
After watching this, it's changed my outlook on things a bit.
Seeing now that an AMOLED panel costs twice as much as an LCD panel sorta restricts the way I now look down on a phone because of the lack of an OLED panel.
Moral Of The Story:
As a tech reviewer I think we should spend less time bashing a product for features that they could've put there and actually look into the quality of the ones that ARE present in the phone (but we're still allowed to rant though, because why not!?😂)

I find it surprising how well the consumer tolerates the removal of absolute necessary stuff from a tech product. Inspite of all the backlash from online platforms such changes never affect the actual sales of a particular product and this is the sole reason why some companies are able to get away with asking more for stuff that's absolutely necessary for a phone. The fact that a phone is removing a headphone jack from a phone to push a product as a necessity is just outrageous. To this day I've had no problems with a good quality wired headphones. But to get that same sound quality and low latency i used to get while gaming on them i have to spend thrice or four times the money i used to spend normally that too for a convenience problem that i never really faced is just outrageous. The real convenience problems i faced actually came after that. Now I have to remember to charge all my Bluetooth earphones and headphones just like my phone which is something I'm not fond of doing. It used to be a product I'd simply use and forget about once I'm done with it. Another fact is that the life of these so called convenient true wireless earphones are so short that you have to replace them atleast every 2 years now considering doing that for an earphone that is quite expensive to buy in the first place, I can't believe the consumers have just allowed themselves to be looted to such extents. The real problem is that the companies have now realized that they can get away with such stuff and here comes the removal of charge bricks from phone boxes without a decrease in prices. If they were really just concerned about the amount of E-waste being produced they could have just made it an optional accessory if a consumer wanted it. Allowing one company to do such stuff makes others realize they too can do it until the point comes when we don't have any options left where a phone might come with a headphone jack or a power brick making it another must have buy for no reason at all. Hope atleast at one point the consumers should stand as one and state that they have enough. It is one of the sole reason I'll never buy an iphone again inspite of really loving it.
Wonder what gets removed next time.

This has been one of the most interesting and informative videos I've seen from a tech channel aimed at someone like me (i.e. not hyper-techy but also not completely indifferent to tech) in a really long time. Watching it felt like the early days of watching tech YouTubers where I came out feeling like I knew more about the general topic than someone who doesn't watch the videos is. It wasn't just reading out specs and telling us what you think about the specs, but an insight into the actual process of design and manufacturing. I'd really really like more videos on this sort of topic exploring how phones are designed, how the Industrial Engineers make decisions, and how cost decisions are made.
After watching this I feel like I have some unique insight into the market that I didn't have before.

Really really appreciated this video and appreciate OnePlus for being willing to do this.

It’s interesting regarding the “ ip68 certification ‘’, because there is quite some flexibility there.

After doing the testing, man-power hours and equipment for testing, a phone company, obviously, learns ‘how to do’ an ip68 certification ‘procedure’ to pass this test;

...so, what would stop a company from simply cutting all those man-power hours, selling-off all the testing equipment, ‘but’ building all future phones with the ‘’same procedures’’ as if it ‘would’ be tested but don’t do the testing, and just delete the word, ‘’certified’’, and just state ambiguously, ‘’ip68’’, as a stand-alone statement; ...sort of like in watches, ‘’water resistent’’ vs. ‘’water proof’’-?

So to answer your last question if anyone is reading, no it does not change my mind. I've always frowned when people try to say something costs $50 to make but companies sell it for $200. Well, there are other costs other than material. I've ALWAYS been saying this.
And it is also in the pc building space. Sure, if you dash build your own pc do it. But to say a company charges $200 extra for the same parts is a stretch. There is staff, overhead, QA, storage costs etc that all need to be factored in. Brand.
